column8: C1. Switzerland currently has a 'two-tier' healthcare system, where wealthier individuals receive better healthcare than others.
column9: C2. A more transparent healthcare system would help people understand costs and make better decisions.
column10: C3. Limiting the influence of private insurance companies in the Swiss healthcare system would help avoid higher costs without improving the quality of care.
column11: C4. It is important to involve more private actors in healthcare (e.g., outsourcing administrative tasks in hospitals to specialized companies) to reduce costs.
column12: C5. Government control of drug prices would prevent pharmaceutical companies from charging excessive prices.
column13: C6. More competition among insurance providers would lead to lower prices and better services.
column14: C7. Reducing the scope of mandatory health insurance coverage could help lower overall healthcare costs.
column15: C8. A public single-payer health insurance system would reduce administrative and marketing costs, making the healthcare system more affordable overall.
column16: C9. More competition in mandatory health insurance, where insurers can offer alternative models, would promote innovation and efficiency in healthcare.
column17: C10. Less government regulation in health insurance would allow for more competitive pricing.
column18: C11. Higher tax deductions for medical expenses would help households manage healthcare costs more effectively.
column19: C12. Health insurance costs should be income-based to make them more affordable for lower-income individuals.
column20: C13. Abolishing mandatory health insurance would reduce the financial burden on households.
column21: C14. As health insurance premiums rise, more households require financial assistance, such as individual premium subsidies, to afford coverage.
column22: C15. Income-based health insurance contributions would make insurance fairer for low-income individuals.
column23: C16. The Swiss healthcare system focuses too much on treating diseases rather than on disease prevention to improve public health.
column24: C17. A lack of financial support for preventive measures leads to higher healthcare costs in the long run.
column25: C18. The current system encourages excessive use of services once the deductible ('franchise') has been paid, leading to unnecessary treatments and higher overall costs.
column26: C19. The increasing demand for healthcare services is mainly due to an aging population that requires more medical care.
column27: C20. Higher out-of-pocket payments would prevent excessive use of healthcare services.
column28: C21. A more centralized healthcare system, such as national hospital planning, would better organize and improve efficiency in healthcare.
column29: C22. Hospitals are more interested in maximizing their profits than in ensuring quality and access to healthcare.
column30: C23. Better coordination between primary care, hospitals, and specialists is essential for the effective treatment of chronic diseases.
column31: C24. Reducing bureaucratic inefficiencies and simplifying administrative processes in healthcare could lead to significant cost savings.
